s1.message: We're using a module ownership system similar to what Mozilla has. While most modules are areas of our code base, some have nothing to do with the code, but are governed in a very similar way.

s3.message: Module owners have functional authority and responsibility over their area. Only the respective super reviewer can overrule their decisions, but this should not be necessary in practice.

s5.message: Review and approve all changes to the module

s8.message: Set the priority of new issues and reject them if necessary

s9.message: Ensure all high priority issues get tackled

s13.message: Ensure good communication with other modules as well as non-developers

s15.message: Each module has a designated super reviewer, who will oversee things at a higher level.

s17.message: While the module owner will review all changes, certain changes should also be reviewed by the super reviewer, in particular:

s18.message: API changes (both public API as well as API between modules)

s21.message: For these types of changes, the module owner should review first and make sure that all of their comments are addressed, then request a super review.

s23.message: There are no reviews for anything happening in non-code modules, but the super reviewers will oversee major projects and communication with other modules and non-developers in a similar fashion. The owner should report to the respective super reviewer on a regular basis.
